title: 110_s524
content:
The "Emergency Farm Assistance Act of 2007" includes provisions for agricultural production losses, small business economic loss grant program, forestry assistance, and aid for unemployed agricultural workers. The "Emergency Farm Assistance Act of 2007" includes provisions for unemployment assistance, food coupons, emergency grants for low-income migrant and seasonal farmworkers, temporary mortgage rental assistance, limits on assistance amount, funding, regulations, and emergency designation. Definitions are also provided. In this Act, a "disaster county" is defined as a county affected by a natural disaster declaration and its contiguous counties. "Livestock" includes cattle, bison, sheep, swine, poultry, and other livestock as determined by the Secretary. A "natural disaster declaration" is a declaration made by the Secretary under specific conditions. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Agriculture. A "specialty crop" is defined as per the Specialty Crops Competitiveness Act of 2004. The term "State" specifically refers to California. SEC. 101. SPECIALTY CROPS. The Secretary will use funds from the Commodity Credit Corporation to provide assistance to specialty crop producers in disaster counties for losses in calendar years 2005, 2006, and 2007. Citrus producers will receive $420 million in assistance for losses in 2007, while other specialty crop producers will receive $438 million. Assistance will be administered by the Secretary in the State under the same terms and conditions. Citrus producers in disaster counties will receive assistance for losses in 2005-2007 under the same terms as special disaster relief programs for crop damage in Florida due to hurricanes in 2004. Uninsured citrus growers can only receive assistance if they did not have crop insurance. Citrus producers affected by disasters in 2005-2007 can receive assistance if they agree to obtain additional crop insurance for the next 3 years. The assistance provided will not exceed 35% of their documented losses, and failure to obtain insurance will result in reimbursement to the Secretary. The Secretary will use funds from the Commodity Credit Corporation to provide dairy producers with payments for production losses in disaster counties in 2006. Additionally, livestock indemnity payments will be made to producers in disaster counties who have incurred losses in 2006 or 2007. Indemnity payments will be at least 30% of the market value of the livestock. SEC. 104. PAYMENT LIMITATION. Assistance under this section may not exceed $125,000 for each farm, ranch, processing plant, or dairy operation. TITLE II--SMALL BUSINESS ECONOMIC LOSS GRANT PROGRAM SEC. 201. SMALL BUSINESS ECONOMIC LOSS GRANT PROGRAM. The Secretary will use funds from the Commodity Credit Corporation to provide grants to States for an expedited disaster assistance program for small businesses that suffered economic losses due to weather-related agricultural losses in specific crop years. To be eligible for a grant under the expedited disaster assistance program, a small business must have less than $15,000,000 in average annual gross income, with at least 75 percent directly related to agriculture. They must also verify economic losses due to weather-related agricultural losses and provide documentation as required by the Secretary and the State. To qualify for a grant under the expedited disaster assistance program, a small business must have less than $15,000,000 in average annual gross income, with at least 75 percent directly related to agriculture. They must demonstrate losses from weather-related agricultural disasters amounting to 15 percent of total economic loss each year a grant is requested. The grant should significantly aid in the business's recovery, continuation of agricultural services, and replanting of production fields and groves, limited to a maximum of 2 years. The subsection for grant eligibility requires documented losses not exceeding 2 years, limited to 75% of average economic loss from weather-related disasters, with a maximum of $250,000 per small business. In case of insufficient funding, proportional reductions may apply to all grants. SEC. 301. TREE ASSISTANCE PROGRAM. The Tree Assistance Program includes assistance for tree, bush, and vine losses. The Secretary will use funds to help producers with tree losses in disaster counties and fruit and tree nut producers. Funds under this section cover costs for tree pruning, rehabilitation, and other tree-related activities as determined by the Secretary. Assistance compensates for losses from disasters in 2005, 2006, or 2007. TITLE IV--ASSISTANCE FOR UNEMPLOYED AGRICULTURAL WORKERS

SEC. 401. UNEMPLOYMENT ASSISTANCE.

The Secretary of Homeland Security will provide unemployment assistance to agricultural workers in the State who are unemployed due to disasters in 2007.

SEC. 402. FOOD COUPONS AND DISTRIBUTION. SEC. 402. The Secretary will use funds from the Commodity Credit Corporation to provide food coupons and surplus commodities to unemployed agricultural workers in the State affected by disasters in 2007. SEC. 403. Emergency grants will be provided to low-income migrant and seasonal farmworkers in the State who are unemployed due to disasters in 2007. SEC. 404. Temporary mortgage rental assistance will also be available. SEC. 404. Temporary mortgage rental assistance will be provided to agricultural workers in the State who are unemployed due to disasters in 2007 for 180 days after the enactment of this Act. TITLE V--MISCELLANEOUS

SEC. 501. LIMIT ON ASSISTANCE: The Secretary will prevent duplicate payments to producers on a farm under this Act and other Federal programs for the same loss.

SEC. 502. FUNDING: The Secretary will utilize Commodity Credit Corporation funds, facilities, and authorities (excluding sections 401 and 404) for this Act, with funds remaining available until expended.

SEC. 503. REGULATIONS: The Secretary will establish regulations for the implementation of this Act. SEC. 503. REGULATIONS: The Secretary may promulgate necessary regulations to implement this Act without following certain provisions, and shall use authority under section 808 of title 5, United States Code. TITLE VI--EMERGENCY DESIGNATION

The amounts provided under this Act are designated as an emergency requirement.
